title: Sausage and Sauerkraut Recipe
description: Sauerkraut and sausage are cooked with bacon, brown sugar, and apple for balanced flavors in this hearty German-inspired dish that will warm you up.

About Us The Allrecipes Allstars How to Add a Recipe GET THE MAGAZINE Recipes Global Cuisines European German Sausage and Sauerkraut 4.7 (291) 235 Reviews 40 Photos This sauerkraut and sausage recipe is from a sweet old German lady I used to attend church with. Allow for plenty of time to prepare and cook this dish. It is definitely worth the time and effort! Serve with hot German potato salad and red cabbage. Submitted by DOEMARK Updated on November 14, 2024 Save Rate Print Share Close Add Photo 40 40 40 40 Prep Time: 15 mins Cook Time: 3 hrs 20 mins Total Time: 3 hrs 35 mins Servings: 5 Jump to Nutrition Facts Cook Mode (Keep screen awake) Ingredients 1x 2x 4x Oops! Something went wrong. Our team is working on it. Original recipe (1X) yields 5 servings 2 pounds sauerkraut, rinsed and drained 1 tablespoon caraway seeds (Optional) ¼ cup brown sugar 1 apple, diced cooking spray ½ pound bacon, cut into 1-inch pieces 1 large onion, chopped 1 ½ pounds kielbasa sausage, cut into 1-inch thick slices Directions Gather the ingredients. Place sauerkraut, caraway seeds, brown sugar, and apple into a large saucepan over medium-low heat, and bring to a simmer. Reduce heat to low, and cook for 2 hours, stirring occasionally. Preheat the oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C). Grease a 9x13-inch baking dish. Place bacon and onion into a skillet over medium heat, and cook until bacon is almost crisp and onion is beginning to brown, about 10 minutes. Stir the bacon mixture into the sauerkraut. Brown kielbasa sausage in remaining bacon grease in the same skillet until sausage begins to brown, 10 to 15 minutes; stir into the sauerkraut mixture. Spoon the sauerkraut and sausage mixture into the prepared baking dish. Bake in the preheated oven until bubbling, about 1 hour. I Made It Print 618 home cooks made it! Nutrition Facts (per serving) 777 Calories 62g Fat 29g Carbs 25g Protein Show Full Nutrition Label Hide Full Nutrition Label Nutrition Facts Servings Per Recipe 5 Calories 777 % Daily Value * Total Fat 62g 80% Saturated Fat 26g 132% Cholesterol 128mg 43% Sodium 2702mg 117% Total Carbohydrate 29g 10% Dietary Fiber 7g 23% Total Sugars 20g Protein 25g 49% Vitamin C 31mg 34% Calcium 84mg 6% Iron 3mg 18% Potassium 509mg 11% * Percent Daily Values are based on a 2,000 calorie diet. Add Your Photo Photos of Sausage and Sauerkraut 01 of 40 Photo by  Allrecipes Member 02 of 40 Photo by  EdgySyrup6416 03/12/2023 I made it as close to recipe as I can and it tasted pretty good. Did not use Caraway seeds as I did not have them. And I added a little chicken stock to it. Topped it with a few Asparagus Spears. 03 of 40 Photo by  Michael Lynch 01/16/2021 Delicious! I like to double the amount of Kielbasa. 04 of 40 Photo by  Phingerpaint 08/29/2020 This recipe is amazing! even better as left overs. it cooked very well in a crock pot on low for a few hours the only changes I made was substitutes the caraway seeds for fennel as thats all I had and used turkey kielbasa because I'm watching my caloric intake 05 of 40 Photo by  Tess Atkinson 02/20/2020 I made it exactly as the recipe instructed and it cane our amazing!! Really concentrated flavors and easy to do, just a tad more time consuming than I’m use to. It was a huge hit with my bf who is half German and I definitely am going to make this again! 06 of 40 Photo by  rachelann 12/29/2019 I made this Dish for our New Years Family dinner and wow was it a Hit!! The sauerkraut had a very balanced taste with the added brown sugar and sliced apple slow cooking together. The bacon and onions brought all the delicious flavoring together and cooking the Keilbassa In the bacon grease enhanced the flavoring even more!! I stayed in line with everything in the recipe, aside from caraway seeds (bc I don’t care for them). The sauerkraut mixture didn’t need anything extra, in my opinion. I think if I would’ve added some kind of extra juice to it, it would’ve thrown the balance off or sweetened it too much. I kept it covered for 2 hours which keeps moisture in while stirring occasionally. Once you add the bacon/onions to it and then the kielbasa, it adds some extra moisture to the sauerkraut and really is perfect flavoring, just as the recipe says! The one thing I would say is to give yourself enough time to sauté the onions/bacon/kielbasa, probably more like 20-25min to sauté up the onions/bacon for good crispness as well as the kielbasa for browning before adding it all the sauerkraut mix. The flavorings bake all together in the oven and the smells in your kitchen are amazing and will bring anyone in your house over to ask, “Is it ready yet!?!” Yum!! Definitely have this recipe saved for one of my future family holiday meals! Thanks for sharing this recipe! 07 of 40 Photo by  DeAnna McClendon 11/21/2019 08 of 40 Photo by  Tracy Bingham 08/18/2019 09 of 40 Photo by  Tracy Bingham 08/18/2019 10 of 40 Photo by  MeowBoops 04/23/2019 This is in the oven now. I know it will be good. However, some things to expect: There is a lot of grease involved. When I cooked the bacon/onions, I scooped it out with a slotted spoon to allow as much excess grease to drip off as possible. When I browned the sausage, I put it on a napkin and also pressed it with more napkins before transferring it to the sauerkraut mixture. I also went through 1-1.5 cups of apple juice while cooking the sauerkraut because it started to get dry. I also bought (unknowingly), Bavarian Caraway Seed sauerkraut, so I didn’t add the additional seeds called for in the recipe. Next time, I know to buy very specific and plain sauerkraut. I tried to cut out as much excess grease as possible but still stick to the recipe as closely as possible. I know it will be very good served over mashed potatoes with a side of lightly dressed baby spinach. Just be aware that this is very greasy, pops a lot, and is best made outside if possible lol. I live in a small apt and this cooking smell will stick around for a few days. 1 2 3 4 Next You’ll Also Love Cheddar Bratzenkraut 2 Ratings German Pork Chops and Sauerkraut 239 Ratings Pork Roast and Sauerkraut 16 Ratings The Original Kielbasa and Sauerkraut 9 Ratings German Style Kielbasa 73 Ratings Slow Cooker German-Style Pork Roast with Sauerkraut and Potatoes 130 Ratings Polish Link Sausage and Cabbage 68 Ratings North German Gruenkohl (Kale) and Sausage 28 Ratings Fried Cabbage and Kielbasa 118 Ratings Beer Sausage 89 Ratings Sausage 'n Kraut 13 Ratings Mennonite Cabbage Potato Kielbasa Bake 126 Ratings Krautburger 77 Ratings Chocolate Sauerkraut Cake II 22 Ratings Cabbage and Smoked Sausage Pasta 196 Ratings Spicy Unstuffed Cabbage 135 Ratings Allrecipes Newsletters Follow Us Dinners Meals Ingredients Occasions Cuisines Kitchen Tips News Features About Us Editorial Process Privacy Policy Product Vetting Terms of Service Advertise Careers Contact Your Privacy Choices   Allrecipes is part of the Dotdash Meredith publishing family. name: DOEMARK
instructions: Gather the ingredients.;Place sauerkraut, caraway seeds, brown sugar, and apple into a large saucepan over medium-low heat, and bring to a simmer. Reduce heat to low, and cook for 2 hours, stirring occasionally.;Preheat the oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C). Grease a 9x13-inch baking dish. Place bacon and onion into a skillet over medium heat, and cook until bacon is almost crisp and onion is beginning to brown, about 10 minutes. Stir the bacon mixture into the sauerkraut.;Brown kielbasa sausage in remaining bacon grease in the same skillet until sausage begins to brown, 10 to 15 minutes; stir into the sauerkraut mixture.;Spoon the sauerkraut and sausage mixture into the prepared baking dish. Bake in the preheated oven until bubbling, about 1 hour.
